metadata.title: Syntactic network analysis in first-episode psychosis: toward generalizability
metadata.abstract: Automated syntactic markers distinguished patients with first-episode psychosis from healthy controls in a Brazilian Portuguese-speaking sample, achieving 81% cross-validated accuracy (AUC = 0.86). These findings largely replicate prior results in Dutch, underscoring the potential of automated syntactic measures to identify early psychosis across languages, illness stages, and speech elicitation tasks.

Automated syntactic markers distinguished patients with first-episode psychosis from healthy controls in a Brazilian Portuguese-speaking sample, achieving 81% cross-validated accuracy (AUC = 0.86). These findings largely replicate prior results in Dutch, underscoring the potential of automated syntactic measures to identify early psychosis across languages, illness stages, and speech elicitation tasks.

Subject termsPsychosisSchizophreniapmc-status-qastatus0pmc-status-liveyespmc-status-embargonopmc-status-releasedyespmc-prop-open-accessyespmc-prop-olfnopmc-prop-manuscriptnopmc-prop-legally-suppressednopmc-prop-has-pdfyespmc-prop-has-supplementyespmc-prop-pdf-onlynopmc-prop-suppress-copyrightnopmc-prop-is-real-versionnopmc-prop-is-scanned-articlenopmc-prop-preprintnopmc-prop-in-epmcyesissue-copyright-statement© Springer Nature Limited 2025

The advancement of Natural Language Processing (NLP) has facilitated the automated analysis of language in patients with schizophrenia-spectrum disorders (SSD). Although NLP models show promise for identifying SSD, clinical utility depends on their cross-linguistic, domain, and methodological generalizability1,2. Cross-linguistic generalizability assesses model performance across different languages. Semantic and acoustic markers of SSD have been shown to vary cross-linguistically3,4, suggesting that these measures can be affected by specific language and cultural differences. Domain generalizability tests model performance across clinical settings (e.g., illness stages) and demographic groups. Currently, the extent to which NLP models for psychosis are influenced by these factors remains unclear5. Methodological generalizability involves, among others, testing the stability of NLP measures across speech elicitation tasks. For instance, picture description and story retelling were more sensitive in identifying psychosis than free speech6.

We previously developed an NLP-based approach for automatically assessing syntactic complexity7, revealing that patients with SSD produce syntactic networks that are smaller, less connected, and less centrally organised than those of healthy individuals, consistent with reduced syntactic complexity. The diagnostic relevance of these measures was supported by associations with human-rated negative symptoms and cognitive scores, and by their ability to identify a SSD diagnosis with clinically meaningful accuracy (74% cross-validated accuracy; AUC = 0.77). Testing these markers in individuals with first-episode psychosis (FEP) is necessary to assess their value for early identification, while minimising confounds related to chronicity and prolonged antipsychotic treatment. We therefore test whether Portuguese-speaking patients with early-stage psychotic illness display a similar reduction in syntactic complexity during a picture description task as previously observed in Dutch-speaking patients with chronic SSD during a semi-spontaneous speech task.

We used data from Mota et al.8, involving 27 individuals who experienced a first episode of psychosis within the past two years and 37 healthy controls. Detailed inclusion criteria are described in Mota et al.8. Symptom severity was measured using the positive and negative syndrome scale (PANSS)9. Participants were shown three neutral images from the International Affective Picture System (IAPS)10. They were asked to focus on each image for 15 s, after which they had to narrate a story based on each picture for at least 30 seconds. These stories were recorded and manually transcribed.

Syntactic complexity was evaluated using the LX Parser11, which generated one constituency tree per utterance. Trees were converted to edge lists for network analysis in Cytoscape (version 3.8.2)12, yielding eleven syntactic network measures (Table 1), as described in ref.7.

Post-hoc comparisons of syntactic network measures between FEP patients and healthy controls.

MeasuresDescriptionFEP (n = 27)Healthy controls (n = 37)p-valuePartial eta squared
Betweenness centralityProportion of shortest paths passing through a node, relative to the total number of shortest paths0.32 ± 0.0210.28 ± 0.018p = 0.184ηp2 = 0.034
DegreeNumber of connections per node1.85 ± 0.0131.92 ± 0.011p < 0.001***ηp2 = 0.242
DiameterThe maximum length of the shortest path between any 2 nodes in the network0.36 ± 0.0210.24 ± 0.018p < 0.001***ηp2 = 0.279
EfficiencyThe average inverse shortest path between all pairs of nodes----
Leaf countTotal number of words19.03 ± 5.13137.43 ± 4.288p = 0.013*ηp2 = 0.114
Leaf fractionProportion of words to the total number of nodes0.50 ± 0.0070.47 ± 0.006p = 0.006**ηp2 = 0.138
Node countTotal number of words and syntactic structures----
Stress centralityTotal number of shortest paths passing through a node1515.85 ± 814.0883361.31 ± 680.293p = 0.109ηp2 = 0.049
LCC node countTotal number of syntactic structures (e.g., noun phrase)----
LCC diameterThe maximum length of the shortest path between any 2 nodes in the LCC----
LCC degreeNumber of connections per syntactic structure2.57 ± 0.0252.71 ± 0.021p < 0.001***ηp2 = 0.249

n sample size, LCC largest connected component, SD standard deviation of the estimates.

Reported values are estimated marginal means ± SD. Reported values are corrected using Bonferroni. Covariate included in the model: age. Measures excluded a priori due to multicollinearity (Pearson r > 0.85): efficiency, node count, LCC node count, LCC diameter.

*Indicates significance at the level of p < 0.05, **p < 0.01, ***p < 0.001.

The distribution of all syntactic measures met the assumption of approximate normality, with skewness coefficients ranging between −2 and +2. For each pair of highly intercorrelated features (Pearson r > 0.85), one feature was discarded, resulting in the exclusion of four features (efficiency, node count, LCC node count, LCC diameter). Group differences in demographic variables were assessed using independent-samples t-tests for age and education and a χ² test of independence for sex. Two multivariate analyses of covariance (MANCOVA) were performed to compare syntactic network measures between patients and controls. The first included diagnostic group and sex as main effects7, with age as a covariate. The second added education as an additional covariate. Bonferroni correction was applied to control for Type I errors in post hoc comparisons.

A random forest (RF) classifier, with 10-fold cross-validation, was trained on the seven syntactic network measures (Table 1) to classify participants as FEP or healthy. Feature importance was estimated using permutation out-of-bag (OOB) importance, defined as the drop in OOB accuracy after randomly permuting each predictor.

Patients were significantly younger than controls (mean age: 18.3 vs 27.9 years, p < 0.001) and had fewer years of education (mean: 7.9 vs 15 years, p < 0.001), with no significant difference in sex distribution between the groups (p = 0.691). Patients had a mean PANSS total score of 68.7 (SD = 15.15). Healthy participants produced significantly more words (185.3 vs 120.2, p = 0.001) and fewer utterances (7.8 vs 16.8, p < 0.001) per interview compared to patients.

The first MANCOVA showed significant effects of diagnostic group (F(7,46) = 2.970, Pillai’s trace = 0.311, p = 0.012) and age (F(7,46) = 3.396, Pillai’s trace = 0.341, p = 0.005) on syntactic measures. No significant effect of sex was found (p = 0.969). Post hoc analyses showed that patients produced syntactic networks with fewer leaves, lower degree, but higher leaf fraction and diameter compared to controls (Table 1). For the Largest Connected Component (LCC), the LCC degree significantly differed between groups. In the second MANCOVA, education did not reach significance (p = 0.083) and, when included, reduced the effects of age (p = 0.053) and diagnosis (p = 0.468) to non-significance; sex was also non-significant (p = 0.971).

The RF model trained on the seven syntactic network measures achieved an accuracy of 81% in identifying a diagnosis of FEP, with 75% sensitivity (confidence interval [CI]: 55–88%) and 85% specificity (CI: 69–93%). The area under the receiver-operating characteristic (AUC-ROC) curve was 0.86 (CI: 0.76−0.96). Diameter was the strongest contributor to classification (Fig. 1).Performance and feature importance of the RF classifier trained on syntactic measures.

A Cross-validated (10-fold CV) AUC-ROC = 0.86 (95% CI: 0.76–0.96). B Permutation importance for the seven syntactic features, expressed as the mean decrease in out-of-bag accuracy when each feature is randomly permuted; higher bars indicate greater importance.

No significant correlations were found between psychotic symptoms, chlorpromazine equivalent dose, and syntactic network measures (all p > 0.05, Supplementary Table S1).

This study demonstrates that our previously developed NLP-based measures of syntactic complexity in psychosis generalise across two languages (Dutch and Portuguese) and illness stages (chronic and FEP), and are robust across tasks (semi-structured interview and picture description). Five out of seven syntactic measures differed between FEP patients and healthy individuals, largely replicating earlier findings in Dutch7. These results align with literature showing a reduction in syntactic complexity in both early and chronic stages of psychosis13,14.

The fact that syntactic markers initially developed for Dutch could be used to classify patients with FEP in Portuguese supports cross-linguistic generalizability of these markers, and points towards a disruption of syntactic organisation in psychosis that goes beyond language-specific properties. In both languages, patients produced syntactic networks with fewer Leaves, lower Degree (less connected), and larger Diameter than controls. Unlike findings in Dutch, Portuguese-speaking patients had a higher proportion of words relative to syntactic structures (i.e., Leaf fraction) than controls, further suggesting decreased structural complexity.

Age and education significantly influenced syntactic complexity. Adding participant education attenuated the diagnostic-group effect, indicating that a substantial portion of the variance in syntactic measures tracks educational attainment. However, because education is linked to illness onset and course, controlling for participants’ education risks underestimating the total effect of illness on syntactic complexity. This aligns with Tang et al.15, who caution against treating education as a confounder when it is itself a primary outcome of psychosis15. Moreover, compared to the Netherlands, Brazil has larger sociodemographic disparities and more uneven access to education, likely magnifying between-group differences in years of schooling and thereby strengthening the attenuation of diagnostic-group differences after adjustment. We lacked cognitive function measures in this cohort, preventing assessment of their relation to syntactic measures and replication of the Dutch findings.

The RF classifier trained on 7 syntactic measures achieved 81% accuracy (AUC-ROC = 0.86; sensitivity = 0.75; specificity = 0.85), indicating clinically meaningful discrimination between individuals with FEP and controls. Notably, the most important feature in the RF (Diameter) also showed the largest group effects in the MANCOVA, supporting convergence between group-level inference and case-level classification. Clinically, syntax-based metrics derived from a 30-second speech sample may offer a low-burden, scalable adjunct for early clinical evaluation at first presentation. Integrating syntactic features with acoustic or semantic markers could further enhance predictive precision and support multimodal early-detection of psychosis.

Future directions include cross-diagnostic comparisons, longitudinal premorbid/prodromal sampling, and replication in larger multilingual cohorts to further assess the generalizability of syntactic markers.

To conclude, quantifying the properties of syntax trees offers a useful approach for analysing syntactic complexity in psychosis, with potential for cross-linguistic, domain, and methodological generalizability.

Although NLP models show promise for identifying SSD, clinical utility depends on their cross-linguistic, domain, and methodological generalizability 1 , 2 . Cross-linguistic generalizability assesses model performance across different languages. Semantic and acoustic markers of SSD have been shown to vary cross-linguistically 3 , 4 , suggesting that these measures can be affected by specific language and cultural differences. Domain generalizability tests model performance across clinical settings (e.g., illness stages) and demographic groups. Currently, the extent to which NLP models for psychosis are influenced by these factors remains unclear 5 . Methodological generalizability involves, among others, testing the stability of NLP measures across speech elicitation tasks. For instance, picture description and story retelling were more sensitive in identifying psychosis than free speech 6 . We previously developed an NLP-based approach for automatically assessing syntactic complexity 7 , revealing that patients with SSD produce syntactic networks that are smaller, less connected, and less centrally organised than those of healthy individuals, consistent with reduced syntactic complexity. The diagnostic relevance of these measures was supported by associations with human-rated negative symptoms and cognitive scores, and by their ability to identify a SSD diagnosis with clinically meaningful accuracy (74% cross-validated accuracy; AUC = 0.77). We used data from Mota et al. 8 , involving 27 individuals who experienced a first episode of psychosis within the past two years and 37 healthy controls. Detailed inclusion criteria are described in Mota et al. 8 . Symptom severity was measured using the positive and negative syndrome scale (PANSS) 9 . Participants were shown three neutral images from the International Affective Picture System (IAPS) 10 . They were asked to focus on each image for 15 s, after which they had to narrate a story based on each picture for at least 30 seconds. These stories were recorded and manually transcribed. Syntactic complexity was evaluated using the LX Parser 11 , which generated one constituency tree per utterance. Trees were converted to edge lists for network analysis in Cytoscape (version 3.8.2) 12 , yielding eleven syntactic network measures (Table 1 ), as described in ref. 7 . The distribution of all syntactic measures met the assumption of approximate normality, with skewness coefficients ranging between −2 and +2. For each pair of highly intercorrelated features (Pearson r  > 0.85), one feature was discarded, resulting in the exclusion of four features (efficiency, node count, LCC node count, LCC diameter). Group differences in demographic variables were assessed using independent-samples t-tests for age and education and a χ² test of independence for sex. Two multivariate analyses of covariance (MANCOVA) were performed to compare syntactic network measures between patients and controls. The first included diagnostic group and sex as main effects 7 , with age as a covariate. The second added education as an additional covariate. Bonferroni correction was applied to control for Type I errors in post hoc comparisons. A random forest (RF) classifier, with 10-fold cross-validation, was trained on the seven syntactic network measures (Table 1 ) to classify participants as FEP or healthy. Feature importance was estimated using permutation out-of-bag (OOB) importance, defined as the drop in OOB accuracy after randomly permuting each predictor. Patients were significantly younger than controls (mean age: 18.3 vs 27.9 years, p  < 0.001) and had fewer years of education (mean: 7.9 vs 15 years, p  < 0.001), with no significant difference in sex distribution between the groups ( p  = 0.691). Patients had a mean PANSS total score of 68.7 (SD = 15.15). Healthy participants produced significantly more words (185.3 vs 120.2, p  = 0.001) and fewer utterances (7.8 vs 16.8, p  < 0.001) per interview compared to patients. The first MANCOVA showed significant effects of diagnostic group (F(7,46) = 2.970, Pillai’s trace = 0.311, p  = 0.012) and age (F(7,46) = 3.396, Pillai’s trace = 0.341, p  = 0.005) on syntactic measures. No significant effect of sex was found ( p  = 0.969). Post hoc analyses showed that patients produced syntactic networks with fewer leaves, lower degree, but higher leaf fraction and diameter compared to controls (Table 1 ). For the Largest Connected Component (LCC), the LCC degree significantly differed between groups. In the second MANCOVA, education did not reach significance ( p  = 0.083) and, when included, reduced the effects of age ( p  = 0.053) and diagnosis ( p  = 0.468) to non-significance; sex was also non-significant ( p  = 0.971). The RF model trained on the seven syntactic network measures achieved an accuracy of 81% in identifying a diagnosis of FEP, with 75% sensitivity (confidence interval [CI]: 55–88%) and 85% specificity (CI: 69–93%). The area under the receiver-operating characteristic (AUC-ROC) curve was 0.86 (CI: 0.76−0.96). Diameter was the strongest contributor to classification (Fig. 1 ). Fig. 1 Performance and feature importance of the RF classifier trained on syntactic measures. A Cross-validated (10-fold CV) AUC-ROC = 0.86 (95% CI: 0.76–0.96). B Permutation importance for the seven syntactic features, expressed as the mean decrease in out-of-bag accuracy when each feature is randomly permuted; higher bars indicate greater importance. No significant correlations were found between psychotic symptoms, chlorpromazine equivalent dose, and syntactic network measures (all p  > 0.05, Supplementary Table S1 ). This study demonstrates that our previously developed NLP-based measures of syntactic complexity in psychosis generalise across two languages (Dutch and Portuguese) and illness stages (chronic and FEP), and are robust across tasks (semi-structured interview and picture description). Five out of seven syntactic measures differed between FEP patients and healthy individuals, largely replicating earlier findings in Dutch 7 . These results align with literature showing a reduction in syntactic complexity in both early and chronic stages of psychosis 13 , 14 . The fact that syntactic markers initially developed for Dutch could be used to classify patients with FEP in Portuguese supports cross-linguistic generalizability of these markers, and points towards a disruption of syntactic organisation in psychosis that goes beyond language-specific properties. In both languages, patients produced syntactic networks with fewer Leaves, lower Degree (less connected), and larger Diameter than controls. Unlike findings in Dutch, Portuguese-speaking patients had a higher proportion of words relative to syntactic structures (i.e., Leaf fraction) than controls, further suggesting decreased structural complexity. Age and education significantly influenced syntactic complexity. Adding participant education attenuated the diagnostic-group effect, indicating that a substantial portion of the variance in syntactic measures tracks educational attainment. However, because education is linked to illness onset and course, controlling for participants’ education risks underestimating the total effect of illness on syntactic complexity. This aligns with Tang et al. 15 , who caution against treating education as a confounder when it is itself a primary outcome of psychosis 15 . Moreover, compared to the Netherlands, Brazil has larger sociodemographic disparities and more uneven access to education, likely magnifying between-group differences in years of schooling and thereby strengthening the attenuation of diagnostic-group differences after adjustment. We lacked cognitive function measures in this cohort, preventing assessment of their relation to syntactic measures and replication of the Dutch findings. The RF classifier trained on 7 syntactic measures achieved 81% accuracy (AUC-ROC = 0.86; sensitivity = 0.75; specificity = 0.85), indicating clinically meaningful discrimination between individuals with FEP and controls. Notably, the most important feature in the RF (Diameter) also showed the largest group effects in the MANCOVA, supporting convergence between group-level inference and case-level classification. Clinically, syntax-based metrics derived from a 30-second speech sample may offer a low-burden, scalable adjunct for early clinical evaluation at first presentation. Integrating syntactic features with acoustic or semantic markers could further enhance predictive precision and support multimodal early-detection of psychosis. Future directions include cross-diagnostic comparisons, longitudinal premorbid/prodromal sampling, and replication in larger multilingual cohorts to further assess the generalizability of syntactic markers. To conclude, quantifying the properties of syntax trees offers a useful approach for analysing syntactic complexity in psychosis, with potential for cross-linguistic , domain , and methodological generalizability.
